comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: According to this: tinyurl.com/kkk9qm Col. Wingate was commander of the 2nd Field Artillery Regiment of the NY National Guard in 1913. These photos are probably taken on the same maneuvers in HIcksville as the ones on previous pages. See: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/3774622759/in/s...

comment.author: 25308510@N08
comment._content: A Colonel George A. Wingate is listed as the commanding officer of the 2nd Field Artillery, Division HQ, N.Y. National Guard located at 171 Clermont Avenue in Brooklyn according to the 1915 edition of the Brooklyn Daily Eagle Almanac (on Google Books).

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Interesting -- the previous two comments on this picture, one of them mine, have been removed.

comment.author: 25308510@N08
comment._content: There were none when I commented but it listed 2 comments after I made mine although only mine appeared.

comment.author: 41068439@N06
comment._content: I don't think this is an artillery unit,  Notice the aide on the col's left, he's carrying a colt .38 model 1909 with butt foreward, spurs and boots scream calvary.  Of course I may be worng artillery was moved by horse at that time ( poss. 1912- 1916).  When do you think the pic was taken?

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content:
He may be visiting a cavalry unit (or vice versa), but I looked at the same source Naidirem did, and Wingate is definitely listed as an artillery commander.  They wouldn't have made a commander walk, would they?

There's a date scratched into the negative at the lower right corner.  Looks like it says "7/8/13"  Definitely 1913.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for the information on the date and identity of Wingate.  We will add it to the description.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Taken at the summer training camp of the New York State National Guard, at Hicksville, Long Island, July 8, 1913.
